channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Actor Jussie Smollett has been sentenced to 150 days in jail for reporting a false hate crime to Chicago police in January 2019 https://t.co/Y5Gnzg4t68
Senate Democrats and Republicans reached an agreement to vote on a $1.5 trillion measure that funds the government and provides aid for Ukraine https://t.co/1EIdDm2NMm

Essay: To show solidarity with Ukraine, many cultural organizations have cut ties with Russia. But ascribing Putin’s brutality to every Russian writer and artist denies the essence of art, writes Suzanne Nossel. https://t.co/P1Oxg3V0Nq
President Biden is expected to announce Friday that the U.S. will join major allies and the EU in calling to revoke normal trade relations with Russia https://t.co/opPfA0h6DH

Ukrainian authorities raised the casualty count of Wednesday’s hospital bombing in Mariupol to three dead and 17 wounded. Vice President Kamala Harris called for a war crimes investigation Thursday, adding that Russia was committing atrocities in Ukraine. https://t.co/VUDpoALnyP

Facebook's parent company has temporarily altered its political expression policy to allow for some use of violent speech, saying exceptions were put in place because of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and allow for speech like “death to the Russian invaders" https://t.co/0zwPXtHmuU

On Thursday 42 Republican senators, led by Sens. Joni Ernst and Mitt Romney, wrote to President Biden that they "strongly disagree with the Defense Department's decision to delay and deny Poland the option to transfer fighter jets to Ukraine." https://t.co/F2lVbf0Tmo

Speaking at the Democratic National Committee meeting, President Biden said the U.S. is “increasing oil production” and said to oil companies: “A time of war is not a time for profit.” https://t.co/sutvMDCJZf
The Pentagon is exploring ways to shore up Ukraine’s air defenses by facilitating the transfer of Soviet-designed antiaircraft systems like the S-300 https://t.co/OnXvE35NtW
Disney said Thursday it is taking steps to pause all other businesses in Russia, a move that comes after it paused the release of films in Russia https://t.co/zyJEKDL25p

French President Emmanuel Macron said on Thursday it would be unfair for the European Union to close the membership door for Ukraine, but warned the bloc couldn’t open an accession process with a country at war https://t.co/tbesmgnKDZ

Vice President Kamala Harris threw her support behind efforts to investigate Russia for possible war crimes in Ukraine, saying the U.S. would work with international efforts that are under way https://t.co/j8EIUEBVUJ

Russia's Ministry of Culture demanded that several Italian museums return paintings and other art works that were loaned to them, as international tension created by Russia's invasion of Ukraine spills over into the art world https://t.co/WxlnldtI3z

From @WSJopinion: The U.S. and Europe have shown impressive cohesion since Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, which makes this week’s fiasco over-delivering Poland’s MiG fighters to Kyiv so damaging https://t.co/HS2hcpOq0C
The Pentagon is exploring ways to shore up Ukraine’s air defenses by facilitating the transfer of Soviet-designed antiaircraft systems like the S-300 https://t.co/GAIpDilrAr
From @WSJopinion: The Allies saved West Berlin from the Soviets in 1948. They should save the Ukrainian city from Putin 2022, writes @DanHenninger https://t.co/4tUGTPItJL

From @WSJopinion: The American people and their leaders need to prepare for a new kind of geopolitical competition—more intense, more dangerous and more aggressive than anything since World War II, writes Seth Cropsey https://t.co/h9nxvNtymz

President Biden is facing calls from some Democrats to push for the suspension of the federal gasoline tax as the next move to counter soaring prices in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/YnxCk51pio
Western Union said Thursday that it is suspending its operations in Russia and Belarus https://t.co/y2jYJ3DAMW
Goldman Sachs said Thursday it was getting out of Russia—the first big U.S. bank to make a move to exit the country after the invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/PpVfgs8Kon

Vice President Kamala Harris called during a visit to Warsaw on Thursday for an investigation into war crimes by Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, and announced humanitarian aid for some of the 1.5 million Ukrainians who have fled to Poland https://t.co/wjcHM5oPDZ
Australia says it will boost uniformed military personnel by 30% to nearly 80,000 https://t.co/m2T4MaqHdk

Potassium-iodide pills that can protect against radiation poisoning are out of stock in much of the U.S., reflecting concerns among some that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine could escalate into a nuclear confrontation or accident that could spread radiation https://t.co/hbUIxUMOXD

Russia said the maternity hospital hit by an airstrike in Mariupol was a legitimate target and that no civilians were present, while video released by the Mariupol mayor’s office showed a pregnant woman and others being carried out of the hospital https://t.co/B1HunMYrxc

The U.S. House passed legislation to block Russian oil imports in an attempt to put its mark on a popular policy proposal in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/VJBvfcCCUi https://t.co/6aR46oxJ5X

Video: While Russia has denied targeting civilians in Ukraine, a WSJ video analysis found that Russian forces bombarded homes, schools and evacuation routes, despite the absence of clear military targets in some areas https://t.co/GDQsjd1OSc

In Ukraine, a ballet dancer, a rock singer, a playwright all take up arms with tens of thousands of Ukrainian civilians to fight Russia’s invasion. "We’re united by wanting to do something useful rather than sitting at home wasting time," said one. https://t.co/za7pJTk9IF
U.S. inflation reached a new four-decade high of 7.9% in February as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine pushed energy prices sharply higher https://t.co/jmaLZ6TKc3
London became Londongrad as Russian oligarchs stormed the high-end property market. Now they are under pressure and so is the real estate market. https://t.co/Fn7Qru6KEc
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has drawn parallels with a global flashpoint far to the east with the potential to set off an even more destructive conflict: Taiwan https://t.co/1I4zuhx6cF
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/T6UEW46Zuk https://t.co/BJNKuhiPwS
The U.K. government sanctioned Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, the owner of soccer club Chelsea FC, over his ties to the Kremlin https://t.co/sO29EEgi28
“Trans-Atlantic strength is back.” NATO finds new purpose in opposing Russia. https://t.co/76y4FaMljX

South Koreans elected Yoon Suk-yeol as president Wednesday, installing a conservative who promises a tougher stance on North Korea and closer ties with the U.S. on regional affairs https://t.co/AvANnQPcjf

Watch: How Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky caught the world’s attention. WSJ looks at how the former television star's use of social media brought his wartime messages to a global audience https://t.co/3cgI8wqfFH
Three Ukrainian refugees are entering Poland every two seconds. Trains are packed, beds are scarce and local governments are scrambling to manage the flood https://t.co/ndtZAV2yO1
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/4VNfJyRl3V https://t.co/fPKwKCC5XB
The wreck of Ernest Shackleton's ship Endurance, which disappeared under Antarctic sea ice in 1915, has been discovered in a "brilliant state of preservation" https://t.co/qXpJ0MySu5
NATO was mired in member disputes just a few years ago. Russia's invasion of Ukraine has given it renewed focus. https://t.co/LndEgabzqc
The U.S. formally rejected a proposal by Poland to give Soviet-era fighter jets to Ukraine, calling the suggested transfer "high risk" https://t.co/ZPhj1fVS7g
Sony said it has stopped selling its PlayStation console and software in Russia, and has shut down the PlayStation Store in the country https://t.co/8ipjiw8HUf

“They want to kill as many civilians as possible,” said the deputy mayor of Mariupol, where more than 1,200 civilians have died after over a week of Russian shelling. “They will not allow for evacuation. They deliberately target lines for water and food.” https://t.co/TNDx1JOck2

The U.S. and its allies are walking a fine line in Ukraine, seeking to help the Ukrainians thwart the Russian invasion while avoiding crossing Russian red lines and getting pulled into a direct conflict with a nuclear-armed adversary https://t.co/Ser2psV6Ku

Watch: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has propelled President Volodymyr Zelensky onto the world stage. We look at how the former television star's use of social media brought his wartime messages to a global audience. https://t.co/Blxsyj2TVE

After Russia denied that it had sustained casualties during the early days of the invasion, Ukraine “decided to show pictures and names of the dead soldiers” on the internet, a Ukrainian official said https://t.co/8EovaYGdwD

From @WSJopinion: Biden bemoans today’s skyrocketing gas prices, yet he remains hostage to the green-energy donors whose policies guarantee higher prices. He is enabling Putin’s energy leverage even as he claims the opposite. https://t.co/4SSdXsQiAV

The European Organization for Nuclear Research has paused new scientific collaborations with Russia, joining other scientific institutions in efforts to isolate Russia after its invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/9tMUTSavXS

United Airlines will allow workers who haven’t been vaccinated against Covid-19 for religious or medical reasons to return at the end of this month, according to people familiar with the decision https://t.co/iwVB1ulknm

White House press secretary Jen Psaki lashed out at Russian claims that the U.S. was developing chemical weapons in Ukraine, warning it could be a pretext for Moscow to use such weapons itself https://t.co/rWqmgKGOWH
“Trans-Atlantic strength is back." NATO finds new purpose in opposing Russia. https://t.co/i20yBuyi5J
